Subject: Aircraft control and parallelizing neat
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=187587090
X-Yahoo-Profile: linteil

It's been a long while since I posted trolling for masters thesis 
ideas, and this is both an update and a request for some advice/sample 
code.

In short, I am examining the differences between recurrent, fixed 
weight networks and networks with dynamic synapses in an adaptive 
control system.  This follows one of Kens papers, but extends it into 
more complex networks.  The general problem area is, as suggested 
previously, aircraft control.  The idea is to maintain level, constant 
speed flight of the aircraft as environmental and/or aircraft 
characteristics change.  This could mean the engine losing power, a 
wing losing lift or control ability, wind changes, etc. Regarding this, 
Im looking for any recommendations for papers to look at, and ideas on 
what kinds of things to toss into the experimental environment.  The 
tentative plan now is to run the aircraft through a number of random 
environments with different changes or combinations of changes, and 
calculate fitness based off of a deviation from the original path as 
compared to the deviation of an aircraft that's done nothing.

The area I could use some help in is with some modifications to the 
original neat code.  Since the aircraft control is fairly complex, I've 
been working at making neat parallel to cut down the time it takes to 
run all this.  Mostly, since this is running on an openmosix cluster, 
this means forking complex procedures that are called from inside a 
loop.  Any other potential locations for speedups?  I've also been 
re-implementing the front end in KDE, since that's usually the 
environment Im working under.  From those who have done re-writes of 
neat before, is there anything in particular I should be especially 
careful of?  Now, where I need help is with implementing plastic 
synapses.  Since I will be comparing this with Ken's original results, 
I'd like to implement them in a manner similar to what Ken had for his 
food foraging experiments.  A rough outline of the implementation, or 
better yet, source code, would be appreciated.

Mark Ahlstrom
